results.title: Harmony Row
results.creator_credit: Frank Thring and Efftee Film Productions
results.brief_description: This production stars George Wallace as a policeman who is assigned to Harmony Row, a notorious haunt of thugs and criminals. On the beat he makes many friends and is finally persuaded to fight Slogger Lee, the biggest trouble maker in Harmony Row, in a boxing tournament.

results.title: Diggers
results.creator_credit: Frank Thring and Efftee Film Productions
results.brief_description: This was the first feature film of the Melbourne enterprise Efftee Films and was adapted for the screen by Pat Hanna from three sketches from his popular Diggers stage show, which featured two Australian cobbers serving in the AIF in France in 1918. The first episode presents the two friends in their attempts to steal rum from a British Army Store; the second episode shows them relaxing in a French cafe while a fellow digger romances with the waitress; the final episode finds the diggers in hospital feigning illness to escape active duty. Cast includes Pat Hanna and George Moon.

results.title: Teenage whiz kids
results.creator_credit: Arthur Mokin Productions and CBS News
results.brief_description:
A CBS News presentation, this film views some gifted children in Washington. Covers the following points regarding gifted children: early entry into tertiary education, emotional maturity, the attitudes of peers, parents, and teachers and the types of problems encountered with early entry to universities and the resultant support needed.
Suitable for teacher/tertiary level.

results.title: All summer in a day
results.creator_credit: Ed Kaplan, Karl Epstein and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description: Based on a short story by Ray Bradbury, this short film is set on a planet where the sun shines for only a few minutes once every nine years. Margot, a frail loner, wistfully recalls her days on sunny Earth and waits longingly for the rare appearance of the sun. But she pays dearly for her sensitivity when, as a victim of teasing, she is locked in a closet for the duration of the event. The other children, overwhelmed by the sun’s warmth, have forgotten and left her there. By the time they release her it’s too late - the rain has begun to fall. This is a tale of the destructive nature of thoughtlessness and cruelty.

results.title: Looking at poems
results.creator_credit: Nuala O'Faolain, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description: Argues that poems demand a special attention and that there is no correct single response to a poem. To emphasise this, three people are shown responding spontaneously after reading the following short lyric poems: “So we’ll go no more a-roving” (Byron), “An Arundel tomb: stanza five” (Larkin), “Love” (Herbert), and “After great pain” (Dickinson). Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: It's one family: knock on wood
results.creator_credit: Tony De Nonno and De Nonno Pix
results.brief_description: An absorbing look at an Italian-American family who continue to carry on a family tradition of some sixty years of operating a marionette theatre. The family makes and paints the marionettes, which are almost life-sized and extremely heavy, makes the armour and other costumes, operates the marionettes, provides the music and sells the tickets. An excellent example of a traditional Sicilian form of theatre.

results.title: George Segal
results.brief_description: This film looks at the life and works of the American sculptor George Segal who invented his own personal style of sculpture: white plaster figures that silently prevail in their own environments, which have been influenced by American townships. The figures are cast from live models, Segal’s family and friends. Shows Segal at work and the controversy aroused by his commisioned piece for Kent University.

results.title: Filming the impossible
results.creator_credit: Aled Vaughan, Leo Dickinson and HTV Limited
results.brief_description: Leo Dickinson is an English cameraman who goes to such lengths as parachuting from 8000 feet or suspending himself from ropes above a gorge to get a better camera angle. This film, narrated by Dickinson, shows footage shot by him in the Himalayas and the Sudan. When a comrade falls 150 feet down a mountain and another nearly drowns in the rapids, Dickinson keeps on filming. Two climbers cling like spiders to a twenty-five degree fall, Dickinson is there too. The footage is so beautifully filmed and well edited that it is hard to believe that it was taken under such bad conditions and without time to erect tripods or wait for the right light. Photographed by Leo Dickinson and edited by Terry Elgar.

results.title: And yet it moves
results.brief_description: This film provides a look at how animators use their imagination; it also shows the materials they use. The film is divided into sections which show the creation of brief but effective story lines or commentaries in various media. Plasticine becomes a gracefully moving woman; another blob becomes a comic singer complete with cape; an egg revolves, bounces and catches fish.

results.title: Walking for physical fitness
results.brief_description: Explains the importance of correct footwear when walking, the benefits of walking and the pleasures walking can bring to all who participate. An informative and motivational film of those who enjoy walking as part of their recreational pursuits.
